sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_1:
Find the determinant of the following $3 \times 3$ matrix:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 
5 & -2 & 3 \\
1 & 0 & 2 \\
-3 & 4 & -1 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$
message_2:
To find the determinant of a $3 \times 3$ matrix, we can use the formula:

$$\det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)$$

where $a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, i$ are the elements of the matrix:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 
a & b & c \\
d & e & f \\
g & h & i \\
\end{bmatrix}$$

In this case, the matrix is:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 
5 & -2 & 3 \\
1 & 0 & 2 \\
-3 & 4 & -1 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$

So, we have:

$$\det(A) = 5(0 \cdot (-1) - 2 \cdot 4) - (-2)(1 \cdot (-1) - 2 \cdot (-3)) + 3(1 \cdot 4 - 0 \cdot (-3))$$

Now, we can compute the determinant:

$$\det(A) = 5(-8) - (-2)(5) + 3(4)$$
$$\det(A) = -40 + 10 + 12$$
$$\det(A) = -18$$

So, the determinant of the given matrix is $-18$.
